p: Furthermore, van der Land and Hummel (2015) conducted a study that focused on the role of education in environmentally induced migration [ 88]. They found that in Mali and Senegal, formal education reduced vulnerability to environmental stressors and as a result reduced migration for economic reasons [ 88]. They attribute this finding to education making individuals less reliant on environmentally sensitive sources of income [ 88]. In contrast, those with lower levels of formal education are substantially more likely to migrate than their counterparts [ 88].
